Edward</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>|ALTERNATIVE NAMES=</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>|SHORT DESCRIPTION=Theoretical mathematician</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>|DATE OF BIRTH=1925</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>|PLACE OF BIRTH=[[Rheydt]], [[Mönchengladbach]], [[Germany]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>|DATE OF DEATH=31 October 2009</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>|PLACE OF DEATH=[[St. Louis, Missouri]], [[United States]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>}}</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Nussbaum, A. Edward}}</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Nussbaum, A. Edward}}</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:333877829:newid:336675501 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 21:38, 8 January 2010</h2> <p><b>A. Edward Nussbaum</b> (<a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a>, 1925 – <a href="/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri" title="St. Louis, Missouri" class="mw-redirect">St. Louis, Missouri</a>, 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Both his father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career there, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967–68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">[2]</a> <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/deathsobituaries/story/B80BEA2EE05A249B86257664000AB277?OpenDocument">Obituary, A. Edward Nussbaum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <ul> <li>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></li> </ul> <table id="persondata" class="persondata noprint" style="border:1px solid #aaa; display:none; speak:none;"> <tr> <th colspan="2"><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Persondata" title="Wikipedia:Persondata">Persondata</a></th> </tr> <tr> <td class="persondata-label" style="color:#aaa;">Name</td> <td>Nussbaum, A. Edward Nussbaum" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr><td colspan='4' style='text-align: center;' class='diff-multi'>(2 intermediate revisions by 2 users not shown)</td></tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>'''A. Edward Nussbaum''' ([[Rheydt]], [[Mönchengladbach]], [[1925]] <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">-</del> [[St. Louis, Missouri]], <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</del>31 October<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</del>2009<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</del>) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of [[Mathematics]] at [[Washington University]] in [[Saint Louis]] for nearly 40 years. Robert Oppenheimer]] and [[John von Neumann]], and was acquainted with [[Albert Einstein]].</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>'''A. He worked with giants of 20th-century [[theoretical physics]] and [[mathematics]] such as [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]] and [[John von Neumann]], and was acquainted with [[Albert Einstein]].</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Early years==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Early years==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 5:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 5:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Nussbaum was born to a [[Jewish]] family in [[Rheydt]], a borough of the [[Germany|German]] city [[Mönchengladbach]] in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a [[Holocaust]] survivor and was orphaned after the [[Nazi]] takeover of Germany.&lt;ref name=STLJ&gt;[http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php] Riley, M, ''Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician'' Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Nussbaum was born to a [[Jewish]] family in [[Rheydt]], a borough of the [[Germany|German]] city [[Mönchengladbach]] in northwestern Germany, in 1925. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were separated and sent on a [[Kindertransport]] to Belgium in 1939.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt; </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the [[Vichy]] regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as [[Œuvre de secours aux enfants#List of OSE orphanages in France during World War II|Château de la Hille]]. He began his teaching career there, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the [[Vichy]] regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as [[Œuvre de secours aux enfants#List of OSE orphanages in France during World War II|Château de la Hille]]. He began his teaching career there, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the [[University of Zurich]],&lt;ref name=WUSTL&gt;http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html] ''WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum'', retrieved November 8, 2009 &lt;/ref&gt; studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in [[New Jersey]] to emigrate to the [[United States]].&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the [[University of Zurich]],&lt;ref name=WUSTL&gt;<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[</ins>http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html] ''WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum'', retrieved November 8, 2009 &lt;/ref&gt; studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in [[New Jersey]] to emigrate to the [[United States]].&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Career==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Career==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 21:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 21:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>In the meantime he had worked at the [[University of Connecticut]] in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>In the meantime he had worked at the [[University of Connecticut]] in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div> </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div> </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">-</del>68 he was a visiting scholar at [[Stanford University]] in Palo Alto, Calif.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&amp;ndash;</ins>68 he was a visiting scholar at [[Stanford University]] in Palo Alto, Calif.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.&lt;ref name=WUSTL/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.&lt;ref name=WUSTL/&gt;</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:331113222:newid:333998255 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 19:57, 25 December 2009</h2> <p><b>A. Edward Nussbaum</b> (<a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a>, <a href="/wiki/1925" title="1925">1925</a> – <a href="/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri" title="St. Louis, Missouri" class="mw-redirect">St. Louis, Missouri</a>, 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Both his father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career there, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967–68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">[2]</a> <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/deathsobituaries/story/B80BEA2EE05A249B86257664000AB277?OpenDocument">Obituary, A. Edward Nussbaum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p> <p><br /></p>   <!--  NewPP Edward Nussbaum'', retrieved November 8, 2009 &lt;/ref&gt; studying both mathematics and physics. He was 84.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">legacy</del>.com<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">/obituaries</del>/stltoday/<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">obituary</del>.<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">aspx</del>?<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308]</del> Obituary, [[Saint Louis Post-Dispatch]], 2 November 2009 &lt;/ref&gt;<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> </del></div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">stltoday</ins>.com/stltoday/<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">news/stories</ins>.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">nsf/deathsobituaries/story/B80BEA2EE05A249B86257664000AB277</ins>?<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">OpenDocument</ins> Obituary,<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> A. Edward Nussbaum] in</ins> [[Saint Louis Post-Dispatch]], 2 November 2009 &lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>== Notes ==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>== Notes ==</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:329560556:newid:333829181 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 16:39, 24 December 2009</h2> <p><b>A. Edward Nussbaum</b> (<a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a>, <a href="/wiki/1925" title="1925">1925</a> - <a href="/wiki/St._Louis,_Missouri" title="St. Louis, Missouri" class="mw-redirect">St. Louis, Missouri</a>, 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Both his father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career there, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html</a>] <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/deathsobituaries/story/B80BEA2EE05A249B86257664000AB277?OpenDocument">Obituary, A. Edward Nussbaum</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p> <p><br /></p>   <!--  NewPP Edward Nussbaum: Difference between revisions</h1> 						<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 									<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div> 								<div id="contentSub"></div> 												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump"> 					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a> 				</div> 				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><table class='diff diff-contentalign-left'> 				<col class='diff-marker' /> 				<col class='diff-content' /> 				<col class='diff-marker' /> 				<col class='diff-content' /> 				<tr style='vertical-align: top;'> 				<td colspan='2' class='diff-otitle'><div id="mw-diff-otitle1"><strong><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._Edward_Nussbaum&amp;oldid=326622571" title="A. He worked with giants of 20th-century [[theoretical physics]] and [[mathematics]] such as [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]] and [[John von Neumann]], and was acquainted with [[Albert Einstein]].</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div><ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">'''</ins>A. He was 84.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">legacy</del>.com<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">/obituaries</del>/stltoday/<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">obituary</del>.<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">aspx</del>?<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308</del>] Obituary, [[Saint Louis Post-Dispatch]], 2 November 2009 &lt;/ref&gt; </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">stltoday</ins>.com/stltoday/<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">news/stories</ins>.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">nsf/deathsobituaries/story/B80BEA2EE05A249B86257664000AB277</ins>?<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">OpenDocument</ins>] Obituary, [[Saint Louis Post-Dispatch]], 2 November 2009 &lt;/ref&gt; </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>== Notes ==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>== Notes ==</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:326622571:newid:331068848 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 10:41, 11 December 2009</h2> <p><b>A. Edward Nussbaum</b> (<a href="/wiki/1925" title="1925">1925</a> - <a href="/wiki/31_October" title="31 October" class="mw-redirect">31 October</a> <a href="/wiki/2009" title="2009">2009</a>) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Both his father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career here, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html</a>] <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stltoday.com/stltoday/news/stories.nsf/deathsobituaries/story/B80BEA2EE05A249B86257664000AB277?OpenDocument">[2]</a> Obituary, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p> <p><br /></p>   <!--  NewPP }</script> <link rel="dns-prefetch" href="//meta.wikimedia.org" /> <!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/static-1.25wmf23/skins/Vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--> </head> <body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-A_Edward_Nussbaum skin-vector action-view"> 		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div> 		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div> 		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main"> 			<a id="top"></a>  							<div id="siteNotice"><!-- CentralNotice --></div> 						<div class="mw-indicators"> </div> 			<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">A. Edward Nussbaum: Difference between revisions</h1> 						<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 									<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div> 								<div id="contentSub"></div> 												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump"> 					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a> 				</div> 				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><table class='diff diff-contentalign-left'> 				<col class='diff-marker' /> 				<col class='diff-content' /> 				<col class='diff-marker' /> 				<col class='diff-content' /> 				<tr style='vertical-align: top;'> 				<td colspan='2' class='diff-otitle'><div id="mw-diff-otitle1"><strong><a href="/w/index.php?title=A._Edward_Nussbaum&amp;oldid=326288033" title="A. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.&lt;ref name=WUSTL/&gt;<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> </del></div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.&lt;ref name=WUSTL/&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"></td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Family==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Family==</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:326288033:newid:329560556 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 23:19, 3 December 2009</h2> <p>A. Edward Nussbaum (1925 - 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Both his father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career here, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html</a>] <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/stltoday/obituary.aspx?n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308">[2]</a> Obituary, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p> <p><br /></p>   <!--  NewPP }</script> <link rel="dns-prefetch" href="//meta.wikimedia.org" /> <!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/static-1.25wmf23/skins/Vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--> </head> <body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-A_Edward_Nussbaum skin-vector action-view"> 		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div> 		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div> 		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main"> 			<a id="top"></a>  							<div id="siteNotice"><!-- CentralNotice --></div> 						<div class="mw-indicators"> </div> 			<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">A.
