Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton]] with [[John Von Neumann]], a renowned <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">mathematician</ins> who used a concept called [[Hilbert space]]s in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:324781917:newid:326622571 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 22:42, 18 November 2009</h2> <p>A. Edward Nussbaum (1925 - 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Both his father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career here, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton" title="Princeton" class="mw-disambig">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p><br /></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html</a>] <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/stltoday/obituary.aspx?n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308">[2]</a> Obituary, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p> <p><br /></p>   <!--  NewPP Edward Nussbaum (1925 - 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of [[Mathematics]]<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> at</del> at [[Washington University]] in [[Saint Louis]] for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century [[theoretical physics]] and [[mathematics]] as [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]] and [[John von Neumann]] and was acquainted with [[Albert Einstein]].</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>A. Edward Nussbaum (1925 - 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of [[Mathematics]] at [[Washington University]] in [[Saint Louis]] for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century [[theoretical physics]] and [[mathematics]]<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> such</ins> as [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]] and [[John von Neumann]]<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">,</ins> and was acquainted with [[Albert Einstein]].</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Early years==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Early years==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div><del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Mr. </del>Nussbaum was born to a [[Jewish]] family in Rheydt, a borough of the [[Germany|German]] city [[Mönchengladbach]] in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a [[Holocaust]] survivor orphaned after the [[Nazi]] takeover of Germany. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Nussbaum was born to a [[Jewish]] family in <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</ins>Rheydt<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</ins>, a borough of the [[Germany|German]] city [[Mönchengladbach]] in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a [[Holocaust]] survivor<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> and was</ins> orphaned after the [[Nazi]] takeover of Germany.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref name=STLJ&gt;[http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php] Riley, M, ''Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician'' Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8,</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">2009&lt;/ref&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div><del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">He and his sister, Lieselotte, survived, but were separated after both were sent on a [[Kindertransport]] to Belgium in 1939. </del>His father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of [[World War I]] <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">in</del> which he <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">was</del> awarded the [[Iron Cross]], and his mother, Franziska<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">,</del> died at [[Auschwitz]]. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>His father, Karl Nussbaum,<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> was</ins> a wounded veteran of [[World War I]]<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">,</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">during</ins> which he <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">had been</ins> awarded the [[Iron Cross]], and his mother, Franziska<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">. Both</ins> died at [[Auschwitz]]. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were were separated and sent on a [[Kindertransport]] to Belgium in 1939.&lt;ref name=STLJ/&gt;</ins> </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the [[Vichy]] <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Regime</del>. He lived there<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> with 100 other children</del> at an orphanage known as [[Œuvre de secours aux enfants#List of OSE orphanages in France during World War II|Château de la Hille]]. <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">It</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">was here that he started</del> his teaching career, <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">as</del> a teenager teaching mathematics to the younger children. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the [[Vichy]] <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">regime</ins>. He lived there at an orphanage known as [[Œuvre de secours aux enfants#List of OSE orphanages in France during World War II|Château de la Hille]]. <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">He</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">began</ins> his teaching career<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> here</ins>, <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">while still</ins> a teenager<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">,</ins> teaching mathematics to the younger children.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">name=STLJ/&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">a university in</del> [[Zurich]], studying both mathematics and physics. In <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">his early 20s</del>, he was sponsored by relatives<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> who lived</del> in [[New Jersey]] to emigrate to the [[United States]].</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">the</ins> [[<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">University of </ins>Zurich]],<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref name=WUSTL&gt;http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html] ''WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum'', retrieved November 8, 2009 &lt;/ref&gt;</ins> studying both mathematics and physics. In <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">1947</ins>, he was sponsored by relatives in [[New Jersey]] to emigrate to the [[United States]].<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref at [[Brooklyn College]] before transferring to <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</ins>Columbia University<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</ins> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref name=WUSTL/&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton]] with John Von Neumann, a renowned <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">mathmetician</del> who used a concept called [[Hilbert space]]s in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Spaces</del> eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and with von Neumann<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">,</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">he</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">wrote</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">several papers</del>. <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Also during</del> this period, Nussbaum became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton]] with <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</ins>John Von Neumann<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</ins>, a renowned <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">mathematician</ins> who used a concept called [[Hilbert space]]s in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">spaces</ins> eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> he wrote several papers</ins> with von Neumann <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">on</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">this</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">topic</ins>. <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">During</ins> this period, Nussbaum<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> also</ins> became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">name=STLJ/&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">name=STLJ/&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>In the meantime he had worked at the [[University of Connecticut]] in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>In the meantime he had worked at the [[University of Connecticut]] in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">name=STLJ/&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div> </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div> </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at [[Stanford University]] in Palo Alto, Calif. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at [[Stanford University]] in Palo Alto, Calif.<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">&lt;ref</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">name=STLJ/&gt;</ins></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Mathematical analysts]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Jewish American scientists]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Columbia University alumni]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Washington University in St. Louis faculty]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:German immigrants to the United States]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:People who emigrated to escape Nazism]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Holocaust survivors]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:German-American Jews]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:People from Mönchengladbach]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:People from St. Louis, Missouri]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:1925 births]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:2009 deaths]]</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:324740623:newid:326288033 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 03:58, 17 November 2009</h2> <p>A. Edward Nussbaum (1925 - 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> such as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a>, and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in <a href="/wiki/Rheydt" title="Rheydt">Rheydt</a>, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor and was orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>His father, Karl Nussbaum, was a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, during which he had been awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska. Both died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed. Nussbaum and his sister, Lieselotte, were were separated and sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> regime. He lived there at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. He began his teaching career here, while still a teenager, teaching mathematics to the younger children.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zurich" title="University of Zurich">University of Zurich</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> studying both mathematics and physics. In 1947, he was sponsored by relatives in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton" title="Princeton" class="mw-disambig">Princeton</a> with <a href="/wiki/John_Von_Neumann" title="John Von Neumann" class="mw-redirect">John Von Neumann</a>, a renowned mathematician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and he wrote several papers with von Neumann on this topic. During this period, Nussbaum also became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p><br /></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957. They had a son, Karl Erich Nussbaum and a daughter, Franziska Suzanne Nussbaum.<sup id="cite_ref-STLJ_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-STLJ-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-STLJ-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-6"><sup><i><b>g</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-7"><sup><i><b>h</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-STLJ_1-8"><sup><i><b>i</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.stljewishlight.com/news/328644400232786.php">[1]</a> Riley, M, <i>Nussbaum was Shoah survivor, accomplished mathematician</i> Saint Louis Jewish Light, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-WUSTL-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-WUSTL_2-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html</a>] <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/stltoday/obituary.aspx?n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308">[2]</a> Obituary, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p> <p><br /></p>   <!--  NewPP 			<div class="portal" role="navigation" id='p-coll-print_export' aria-labelledby='p-coll-print_export-label'> 			<h3 id='p-coll-print_export-label'>Print/export</h3>  			<div class="body"> Edward Nussbaum" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 32:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 32:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/stltoday/obituary.aspx?n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308] Obituary, [[Saint Louis Post-Dispatch]], 2 November 2009 &lt;/ref&gt; </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>== <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">References</del> ==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>== <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Notes</ins> ==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{reflist}}</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{reflist}}</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>==References==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Nussbaum, A. Edward, [http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252 ''A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space'']</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:324740623:newid:324741633 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 00:02, 9 November 2009</h2> <p>A. Edward Nussbaum (1925 - 31 October 2009) was a theoretical mathematician and professor of <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">Mathematics</a> at at <a href="/wiki/Washington_University" title="Washington University" class="mw-redirect">Washington University</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis" title="Saint Louis" class="mw-disambig">Saint Louis</a> for nearly 40 years. He worked with giants of 20th-century <a href="/wiki/Theoretical_physics" title="Theoretical physics">theoretical physics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mathematics" title="Mathematics">mathematics</a> as <a href="/wiki/J._Robert_Oppenheimer" title="J. Robert Oppenheimer">J. Robert Oppenheimer</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_von_Neumann" title="John von Neumann">John von Neumann</a> and was acquainted with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein" title="Albert Einstein">Albert Einstein</a>.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Early_years"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Early years</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Career"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Career</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#Family"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Family</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#Death"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Death</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-5"><a href="#Notes"><span class="tocnumber">5</span> <span class="toctext">Notes</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-6"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_years">Early years</span></h2> <p>Mr. Nussbaum was born to a <a href="/wiki/Jewish" title="Jewish" class="mw-redirect">Jewish</a> family in Rheydt, a borough of the <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">German</a> city <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B6nchengladbach" title="Mönchengladbach">Mönchengladbach</a> in northwestern Germany, in 1925. The youngest of three children, he was a <a href="/wiki/Holocaust" title="Holocaust" class="mw-redirect">Holocaust</a> survivor orphaned after the <a href="/wiki/Nazi" title="Nazi" class="mw-redirect">Nazi</a> takeover of Germany.</p> <p>He and his sister, Lieselotte, survived, but were separated after both were sent on a <a href="/wiki/Kindertransport" title="Kindertransport">Kindertransport</a> to Belgium in 1939. His father, Karl Nussbaum, a wounded veteran of <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a> in which he was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Cross" title="Iron Cross">Iron Cross</a>, and his mother, Franziska, died at <a href="/wiki/Auschwitz" title="Auschwitz" class="mw-redirect">Auschwitz</a>. His brother, Erwin Nussbaum, was also captured and killed.</p> <p>When Belgium was invaded by Germany, Nussbaum escaped to southern France, then under the <a href="/wiki/Vichy" title="Vichy">Vichy</a> Regime. He lived there with 100 other children at an orphanage known as <a href="/wiki/%C5%92uvre_de_secours_aux_enfants#List_of_OSE_orphanages_in_France_during_World_War_II" title="Œuvre de secours aux enfants">Château de la Hille</a>. It was here that he started his teaching career, as a teenager teaching mathematics to the younger children.</p> <p>After being captured twice, and jailed once by the Nazis, he escaped on foot to Switzerland, where he attended a university in <a href="/wiki/Zurich" title="Zurich" class="mw-redirect">Zurich</a>, studying both mathematics and physics. In his early 20s, he was sponsored by relatives who lived in <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> to emigrate to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.</p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career">Career</span></h2> <p>Shortly after emigrating to the United States, he studied mathematics at <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_College" title="Brooklyn College">Brooklyn College</a> before transferring to Columbia University in New York where he earned his master of arts degree in 1950 and his Ph.D. in 1957.</p> <p>While writing his thesis for Columbia, he worked at the <a href="/wiki/Institute_for_Advanced_Study" title="Institute for Advanced Study">Institute for Advanced Study</a> in <a href="/wiki/Princeton" title="Princeton" class="mw-disambig">Princeton</a> with John Von Neumann, a renowned mathmetician who used a concept called <a href="/wiki/Hilbert_space" title="Hilbert space">Hilbert spaces</a> in his development of the mathematical basis of modern computer language. Hilbert Spaces eventually became Nussbaum's area of expertise and with von Neumann, he wrote several papers. Also during this period, Nussbaum became acquainted with Albert Einstein, another of the original group at the Institute for Advanced Study.</p> <p>Notably, Nussbaum's thesis was accepted with no revisions and he received his doctorate shortly thereafter.</p> <p>In the meantime he had worked at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Connecticut" title="University of Connecticut">University of Connecticut</a> in Storrs, where he co-authored papers with Allen Devinatz, and at the <a href="/wiki/Rensselaer_Polytechnic_Institute" title="Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute">Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute</a> in Troy, N.Y. He followed Devinatz to St. Louis to teach at Washington University in 1958.</p> <p>In 1962, he was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Studies working with Robert Oppenheimer; in 1967-68 he was a visiting scholar at <a href="/wiki/Stanford_University" title="Stanford University">Stanford University</a> in Palo Alto, Calif.</p> <p>He joined Washington University's mathematics faculty as an assistant professor in 1958. He became a full professor in 1966 and taught until 1995, when he was named an emeritus professor.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Family">Family</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum married his cousin's sister-in-law, Anne Ebbin, on September 1, 1957.</p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Death">Death</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum died 31 October 2009. He was 84.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://news-info.wustl.edu/news/page/normal/15035.html">[1]</a> <i>WUSTL flag at half-staff in honor of A. Edward Nussbaum</i>, retrieved November 8, 2009</span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/stltoday/obituary.aspx?n=a-edward-nussbaum&amp;pid=135342308">[2]</a> Obituary, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Louis_Post-Dispatch" title="Saint Louis Post-Dispatch" class="mw-redirect">Saint Louis Post-Dispatch</a>, 2 November 2009</span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <p>Nussbaum, A. Edward, <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/pss/2162252"><i>A Commutativity Theorem for Semi-Bounded Operators in Hilbert Space</i></a></p>   <!--  NewPP limit report Parsed by mw1174 CPU time usage: 0.033 seconds Real time usage: 0.040 seconds Preprocessor visited node count: 153/1000000 Preprocessor generated node count: 0/1500000 Post‐expand include size: 165/2097152 bytes Template argument size: 0/2097152 bytes Highest expansion depth: 4/40 Expensive parser function count: 0/500 -->  <!--  Transclusion expansion time report (%,ms,calls,template) 100.00%    5.098      1 - Template:Reflist 100.00%    5.098      1 - -total --> <noscript><img src="//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:CentralAutoLogin/start?type=1x1" alt="" title="" width="1" height="1" style="border: none; position: absolute;" /></noscript></div>									<div class="printfooter"> 						Retrieved from "<a dir="ltr" href="http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=A._Edward_Nussbaum&amp;oldid=324741633">http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=A._Edward_Nussbaum&amp;oldid=324741633</a>"					</div> 													<div id='catlinks' class='catlinks catlinks-allhidden'></div>												<div class="visualClear"></div> 							</div> 		</div> 		<div id="mw-navigation"> 			<h2>Navigation menu</h2>  			<div id="mw-head"> 									<div id="p-personal" role="navigation" class="" aria-labelledby="p-personal-label"> 						<h3 id="p-personal-label">Personal tools</h3> 						<ul> 							<li id="pt-createaccount"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:UserLogin&amp;returnto=A.+Edward+Nussbaum&amp;returntoquery=diff%3D324741633%26oldid%3D324740623&amp;type=signup" title="You are encouraged to create an account and log in; however, it is not mandatory">Create account</a></li><li id="pt-login"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Special:UserLogin&amp;returnto=A.+Edward+Nussbaum&amp;returntoquery=diff%3D324741633%26oldid%3D324740623" title="You're encouraged to log in; however, it's not mandatory. unlinking bot">contribs</a>)</span></div><div id="mw-diff-otitle3"><abbr class='minoredit' title='This is a minor edit'>m</abbr> <span class="comment">(Unlinking full-dates. <a href="/wiki/User:Full-date_unlinking_bot" title="User:Full-date unlinking bot">Details here</a>. Codes: ISO1(×1))</span></div><div id="mw-diff-otitle5"></div><div id="mw-diff-otitle4"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Gordon_(Scottish_author)&amp;diff=prev&amp;oldid=330559570" title="Richard Gordon (Scottish author)" id="differences-prevlink">← Previous edit</a></div></td> 				<td colspan='2' class='diff-ntitle'><div id="mw-diff-ntitle1"><strong><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Gordon_(Scottish_author)&amp;oldid=335481420" title="Richard Gordon (Scottish author)">Revision as of 17:21, 2 January 2010</a> <span class="mw-diff-edit">(<a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Gordon_(Scottish_author)&amp;action=edit&amp;oldid=335481420" title="Richard Gordon (Scottish author)">edit</a>)</span> <span class="mw-diff-undo">(<a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Gordon_(Scottish_author)&amp;action=edit&amp;undoafter=330559570&amp;undo=335481420" title="&quot;Undo&quot; reverts this edit and opens the edit form in preview mode. It allows adding a reason in the summary.">undo</a>)</span></strong></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle2"><a href="/wiki/User:Cnilep" title="User:Cnilep" class="mw-userlink">Cnilep</a> <span class="mw-usertoollinks">(<a href="/wiki/User_talk:Cnilep" title="User talk:Cnilep">talk</a> | <a href="/wiki/Special:Contributions/Cnilep" title="Special:Contributions/Cnilep">contribs</a>)</span> </div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle3"><abbr class='minoredit' title='This is a minor edit'>m</abbr> <span class="comment">(Rm external links to social networking sites per <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:ELNO" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:ELNO">WP:ELNO</a>)</span></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle5"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle4"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Gordon_(Scottish_author)&amp;diff=next&amp;oldid=335481420" title="Richard Gordon (Scottish author)" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr><td colspan='4' style='text-align: center;' class='diff-multi'>(2 intermediate revisions by one other user not shown)</td></tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 49:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 49:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>== Life ==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>== Life ==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>*[http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=74312391752 悼念Mr. Richard Gordon], memorial page at [[Facebook]] - must login to site to access</div></td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Gordon, Richard}}</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Gordon, Richard}}</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:330559570:newid:335481420 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 17:21, 2 January 2010</h2> <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"> <tr> <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><span class="fn">Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</span></th> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Richard Gordon Shanghai China 2007.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 in Shanghai, China holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff,_Aberdeenshire" title="Banff, Aberdeenshire">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at the Cairnfield estate near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a>, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The complete Moray rambler</i> (1992) - Published under Richard Gordon <sup id="cite_ref-openluib_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-openluib-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | first = </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | first = </div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:328405147:newid:331007424 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 02:34, 11 December 2009</h2> <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"> <tr> <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><span class="fn">Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</span></th> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Richard Gordon Shanghai China 2007.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 in Shanghai, China holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff,_Aberdeenshire" title="Banff, Aberdeenshire">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at the Cairnfield estate near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The complete Moray rambler</i> (1992) - Published under Richard Gordon <sup id="cite_ref-openluib_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-openluib-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-locus-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><span id="CITEREF2009" class="citation">"Obituaries", <i><a href="/wiki/Locus_(magazine)" title="Locus (magazine)">Locus</a></i>, March 2009: 61</span><span
