//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 in Shanghai, China holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff,_Aberdeenshire" title="Banff, Aberdeenshire">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cairnfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cairnfield (page does not exist)">Cairnfield</a> near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The complete Moray rambler</i> (1992) - Published under Richard Gordon <sup id="cite_ref-openluib_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-openluib-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div an account and log in; however, it is not mandatory">Create account</a></li><li id="pt-login"><a [[travel guide]]s.&lt;ref name=locus&gt;{{Citation</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>'''Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon''' (18 May 1947 &amp;ndash; 7 [[Shanghai Metro]] of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.&lt;ref name=locus/&gt;&lt;ref&gt;http://www.shs.sh.cn/News/modules/newsmanager/shownews.aspx?NewsID=8580<del class="diff-context"><div>==References==</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:314222260:newid:328404332 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 16:46, 28 November 2009</h2> <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"> <tr> <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><span class="fn">Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</span></th> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Richard Gordon Shanghai China 2007.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff,_Aberdeenshire" title="Banff, Aberdeenshire">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cairnfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cairnfield (page does not exist)">Cairnfield</a> near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The complete Moray rambler</i> (1992) - Published under Richard Gordon <sup id="cite_ref-openluib_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-openluib-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="diff-addedline"><div>== Life ==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. His family's home is located at [[Cairnfield]] near [[Arradoul]]. Gordon studied history at [[Newcastle University]] and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. His family's home is located at [[Cairnfield]] near [[Arradoul]]. Gordon studied history at [[Newcastle University]] and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 63:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 63:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | url =http://www.northern-scot.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/7644/An_intellectual_traveller.html }}&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | url =http://www.northern-scot.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/7644/An_intellectual_traveller.html }}&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for [[<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">New_Worlds_</del>(magazine)|New Worlds]] in 1965 as '''Richard A. Gordon.''' Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the [[Richard Gordon (English author)|author]] of the ''[[Doctor Series|Doctor]]'' books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name '''Alex Stuart''', but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published [[<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Historical_fiction|</del>historical fiction]] under that name.  He then adopted the name '''Alex R. Stuart''' and later took on the pen name '''Stuart Gordon'''.&lt;ref name=locus/&gt; Gordon's later work was published under his own name. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for [[<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">New Worlds </ins>(magazine)|New Worlds]] in 1965 as '''Richard A. Gordon.''' Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the [[Richard Gordon (English author)|author]] of the ''[[Doctor Series|Doctor]]'' books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name '''Alex Stuart''', but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published [[historical fiction]] under that name.  He then adopted the name '''Alex R. Stuart''' and later took on the pen name '''Stuart Gordon'''.&lt;ref name=locus/&gt; Gordon's later work was published under his own name. </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the ''The Bikers'': To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff,_Aberdeenshire" title="Banff, Aberdeenshire">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cairnfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cairnfield (page does not exist)">Cairnfield</a> near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>== Life ==<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> </del></div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>== Life ==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. His family's home is located at [[Cairnfield]] near [[Arradoul]]. Gordon studied history at [[Newcastle University]] and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. His family's home is located at [[Cairnfield]] near [[Arradoul]]. Gordon studied history at [[Newcastle University]] and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 63:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 63:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | url =http://www.northern-scot.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/7644/An_intellectual_traveller.html }}&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | url =http://www.northern-scot.co.uk/news/fullstory.php/aid/7644/An_intellectual_traveller.html }}&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for [[<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">New_Worlds_</del>(magazine)|New Worlds]] in 1965 as '''Richard A. Gordon.''' Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the [[Richard Gordon (English author)|author]] of the ''[[Doctor Series|Doctor]]'' books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name '''Alex Stuart''', but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published [[<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Historical_fiction|</del>historical fiction]] under that name.  He then adopted the name '''Alex R. Stuart''' and later took on the pen name '''Stuart Gordon'''.&lt;ref name=locus/&gt; Gordon's later work was published under his own name. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for [[<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">New Worlds </ins>(magazine)|New Worlds]] in 1965 as '''Richard A. Gordon.''' Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the [[Richard Gordon (English author)|author]] of the ''[[Doctor Series|Doctor]]'' books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name '''Alex Stuart''', but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published [[historical fiction]] under that name.  He then adopted the name '''Alex R. Stuart''' and later took on the pen name '''Stuart Gordon'''.&lt;ref name=locus/&gt; Gordon's later work was published under his own name. </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the ''The Bikers'': To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the ''The Bikers'': To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano. </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 108:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 108:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>*[http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/g/stuart-gordon/ Stuart Gordon at Fantasticfiction.co.uk]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>*[http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/g/stuart-gordon/ Stuart Gordon at Fantasticfiction.co.uk]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr> <td class="diff-addedline"><div>{{<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">DEFAULTSORT:</ins>Gordon, Richard}}</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td  <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Alumni of Newcastle University]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Scottish novelists]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Scottish novelists]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Scottish science fiction writers]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Travel</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Writers</del>]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Scottish <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">travel</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">writers</ins>]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Deaths from myocardial infarction]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:People from Buckie]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:People from Buckie]]</div></td> </tr>  <!-- diff cache key enwiki:diff:version:1.11a:oldid:293714506:newid:314222260 --> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 23:48, 15 September 2009</h2> <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"> <tr> <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><span class="fn">Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</span></th> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Richard Gordon Shanghai China 2007.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff_and_Macduff" title="Banff and Macduff" class="mw-disambig">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cairnfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cairnfield (page does not exist)">Cairnfield</a> near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 18:49, 10 July 2009</h2> <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"> <tr> <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><span class="fn">Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</span></th> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Richard Gordon Shanghai China 2007.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff_and_Macduff" title="Banff and Macduff" class="mw-disambig">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cairnfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cairnfield (page does not exist)">Cairnfield</a> near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div Bike from Hell'' and ''The Devil’s Rider''</del></div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>| <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">imagesize</ins>    = class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>== Life == </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. His family's home is located at [[Cairnfield]] near [[Arradoul]]. Gordon studied history at [[Newcastle University]] and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Gordon was brought up and educated in [[Buckie]] and [[Perthshire]]. His family's home is located at [[Cairnfield]] near [[Arradoul]]. Gordon studied history at [[Newcastle University]] and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.&lt;ref name=nscot&gt;{{Citation</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>  | last = </div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 13:15, 1 June 2009</h2> <table class="infobox vcard" style="width:22em"> <tr> <th colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-size:125%;font-weight:bold"><span class="fn">Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</span></th> </tr> <tr> <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="Richard Gordon Shanghai China 2007.JPG" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div>Richard Gordon in 2007 holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Pen name</th> <td class="nickname" style="line-height:1.4em;">Alex Stuart, Alex R. Stuart, Stuart Gordon</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Occupation</th> <td class="role" style="line-height:1.4em;">Writer, Teacher</td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Ethnicity</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Genre</th> <td class="category" style="line-height:1.4em;"><a href="/wiki/Science_Fiction" title="Science Fiction" class="mw-redirect">Science Fiction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Travel_literature" title="Travel literature">Travel literature</a></td> </tr> <tr> <th scope="row" style="text-align:left;padding-top:0.225em;line-height:1.1em;padding-right:0.65em;">Relatives</th> <td style="line-height:1.4em;">David Gordon (brother), mother</td> </tr> </table> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (18 May 1947 – 7 February 2009) was a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff_and_Macduff" title="Banff and Macduff" class="mw-disambig">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who wrote numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p></p> <div id="toc" class="toc"> <div id="toctitle"> <h2>Contents</h2> </div> <ul> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-1"><a href="#Life"><span class="tocnumber">1</span> <span class="toctext">Life</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-2"><a href="#Partial_list_of_works"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Partial list of works</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-3"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li> <li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-4"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li> </ul> </div> <p></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Life">Life</span></h2> <p>Gordon was brought up and educated in <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Perthshire" title="Perthshire">Perthshire</a>. His family's home is located at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cairnfield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cairnfield (page does not exist)">Cairnfield</a> near <a href="/wiki/Arradoul" title="Arradoul">Arradoul</a>. Gordon studied history at <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_University" title="Newcastle University">Newcastle University</a> and was offered post-graduate work, but instead he accepted a job as a market researcher. He later left this position and made a career as a writer.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Gordon began publishing science fiction with "A Light in the Sky" for <a href="/wiki/New_Worlds_(magazine)" title="New Worlds (magazine)">New Worlds</a> in 1965 as <b>Richard A. Gordon.</b> Later his publisher ask him to adopt a pseudonym for the risk of confusing him with the <a href="/wiki/Richard_Gordon_(English_author)" title="Richard Gordon (English author)">author</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Series" title="Doctor Series">Doctor</a></i> books. Gordon initially adopted the pen name <b>Alex Stuart</b>, but was again asked to change names due to complaints from author Violet Vivian Stuart, who published <a href="/wiki/Historical_fiction" title="Historical fiction">historical fiction</a> under that name. He then adopted the name <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and later took on the pen name <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon's later work was published under his own name.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In his writing, Gordon often made reference to his Moray roots.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>In the 1990s he produced a series of illustrated walking and local history guides of northern Scotland. In addition, he wrote several articles under the pen name <i>The Moray Rambler</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>After many years of writing, Gordon moved to London, where he took a course in teaching English as a foreign language. Gordon began teaching abroad in his 50s.<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> He first taught in Poland,<sup id="cite_ref-nscot_2-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nscot-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> and then in 2003 he relocated to China.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Gordon collapsed at the <a href="/wiki/Lianhua_Road_(Shanghai_Metro)" title="Lianhua Road (Shanghai Metro)" class="mw-redirect">Lianhua Road Subway Station</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Metro" title="Shanghai Metro">Shanghai Metro</a> of a heart attack and died in hospital on February 7, 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> He had been teaching at <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_High_School_International_Division" title="Shanghai High School International Division">Shanghai High School International Division</a> since 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-locus_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-locus-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a></i> (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a></i> (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a></i> (1972)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a></i> (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a></i> (1973)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a></i> (1974)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a></i> (1975)</li> <li><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a></i> (1981)</li> <li><i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History</i> (1998) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History</i> (1999) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron</i> (2000) - Published as Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-locus-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-locus_1-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><span id="CITEREF2009" class="citation">"Obituaries", <i><a href="/wiki/Locus_(magazine)" title="Locus (magazine)">Locus</a></i>, March 2009: 61</span><span and year (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_Date_and_year" title="Category:CS1 maint: Date and year">link</a>)</span></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a
