<tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Partial list of works==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==Partial list of works==</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 08:39, 8 February 2009</h2> <div class="thumb tright"> <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/220px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/330px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG/440px-Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a> <div class="thumbcaption"> <div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Richard_Gordon_Shanghai_China_2007.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div> Richard Gordon in 2007 holding two of his earliest works, <i>The Bike from Hell</i> and <i>The Devil’s Rider</i></div> </div> </div> <p><b>Richard Alexander Steuart Gordon</b> (b. 1947) is a <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scottish</a> author born in <a href="/wiki/Banff_and_Macduff" title="Banff and Macduff" class="mw-disambig">Banff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> who has written numerous <a href="/wiki/Science_fiction" title="Science fiction">science fiction</a> novels, <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedias" title="Encyclopedias" class="mw-redirect">encyclopedias</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Travel_guide" title="Travel guide" class="mw-redirect">travel guides</a>. Gordon's novels are noted for their mix of historical fact and creative fictionalized events.</p> <p>Due to objections from publishers to his using his given name--because there was already a published Richard Gordon--Gordon published many of his best known works under the <a href="/wiki/Pen_names" title="Pen names" class="mw-redirect">pen names</a> <b>Alex R. Stuart</b> and <b>Stuart Gordon</b>.</p> <p>One interesting note of Gordon's work is the colorful dedications he had in his earliest works, such as the following dedication for the <i>The Bikers</i>: To She Who Types Like a Drunken Midget Playing The Piano.</p> <p>While Gordon has never written fictional pieces set in Scotland, the characters in his books occasionally pass through his hometown. In <i><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a></i> time-warped Sir <a href="/wiki/Humphrey_Gilbert" title="Humphrey Gilbert">Humphrey Gilbert</a> passes through <a href="/wiki/Buckie" title="Buckie">Buckie</a>, where Gordon grew up.</p> <p>Gordon collapsed and died in a Shanghai train station while teaching in <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a> on February 7, 2009.</p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Partial_list_of_works">Partial list of works</span></h2> <p>Works are published under pseudonym Stuart Gordon unless otherwise noted.</p> <ul> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bikers</a>. (1971) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Outlaws</a>. (1972)- published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Story&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Story (page does not exist)">Time Story</a> (1972)</li> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Bike from Hell</a>. (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Bikers_(novel_series)" title="The Bikers (novel series)">The Devil's Rider</a>. (1973) - published under pen name Alex R. Stuart</li> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">One-Eye</a>. (1973)</li> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Two-Eyes</a> (1974)</li> <li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Suaine_and_the_Crow-God.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Suaine and the Crow-God. (page does not exist)">Suaine and the Crow-God.</a> (1975)</li> <li><a href="/wiki/The_Eyes_(novel_series)" title="The Eyes (novel series)">Three-Eyes</a> (1975)</li> <li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_on_the_void:_The_mythhistory_of_Ralph_M%27Botu_Kitaj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj (page does not exist)">Smile on the void: The mythhistory of Ralph M'Botu Kitaj</a> (1981)</li> <li><a href="/wiki/Fire_in_the_Abyss" title="Fire in the Abyss">Fire in the Abyss</a>. (1983)</li> <li><i>Archon.</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>The Hidden World.</i> (1988)</li> <li><i>Down the Drain: Water, Pollution and Privatisation.</i> (1989) - with coauthor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jennie_Smith&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jennie Smith (page does not exist)">Jennie Smith</a></li> <li><i>The Mask.</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>Eye in the Stone.</i> (1990)</li> <li><i>The Paranormal: An Illustrated Encyclopedia.</i> (1992)</li> <li><i>The Encyclopedia of Myths and Legends.</i> (1993)</li> <li><i>The Book of Miracles: From Lazarus to Lourdes.</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Hoaxes: An A-Z of famous fakes, frauds and cons.</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>The Book of Curses: True Tales of Voodoo, Hoodoo and Hex.</i> (1995)</li> <li><i>Round Iverness, The Black Isle and Nairn: Walks and History.</i> (1998) - Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Moray, Badenoch and Strathspey: Walks and History.</i> (1999)- Published under Richard Gordon</li> <li><i>Round Aberdeen from Beeside to the Deveron.</i> (2000)- Published under Richard Gordon</li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/g/stuart-gordon/">Stuart Gordon at Fantasticfiction.co.uk</a></li> </ul> <table class="metadata plainlinks stub" role="presentation" style="background:transparent"> <tr> <td><a href="/wiki/File:Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg" class="image"><img alt="Stub icon" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg/30px-Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg.png" width="30" height="24" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg/45px-Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg/60px-Nuvola_apps_konquest.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="130" data-file-height="105" /></a></td> <td><i>This article about a science fiction writer is a <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Stub" title="Wikipedia:Stub">stub</a>. You can help Wikipedia by <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Richard_Gordon_(Scottish_author)&amp;action=edit">expanding it</a>.</i> <div class="plainlinks hlist The [[RFU]] were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.  </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when [[Oxford University]] beat [[South Africa]] 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal [[Gareth Edwards]] of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-[[Ireland]] international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.&lt;ref&gt;[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/ Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75]  ''NBC Sports''&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849  Former referee Titcomb dies at 75]  ''24.com''&lt;/ref&gt; Titcomb later apologized for his call. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when [[Oxford University]] beat [[South Africa]] 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline"> to</ins> [[Gareth Edwards]] of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-[[Ireland]] international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.&lt;ref&gt;[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/ Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75]  ''NBC Sports''&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849  Former referee Titcomb dies at 75]  ''24.com''&lt;/ref&gt; Titcomb later apologized for his call. </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>Titcomb died of [[kidney failure]] on 2 May<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">,</del> 2008.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php  Former top referee Titcomb dies]  ''scrum.com''&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>Titcomb died of [[kidney failure]] on 2 May 2008.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php  Former top referee Titcomb dies]  ''scrum.com''&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==References==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==References==</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 19:32, 16 April 2009</h2> <p><b>Michael Herbert Titcomb</b> (<a href="/wiki/23_April" title="23 April" class="mw-redirect">23 April</a>, <a href="/wiki/1933" title="1933">1933</a> - <a href="/wiki/2_May" title="2 May" class="mw-redirect">2 May</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008" title="2008">2008</a>) was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> referee. He became the youngest referee to officiate and international game when <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> in 1966.</p> <p>Born <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, <a href="/wiki/Bristol_University" title="Bristol University" class="mw-redirect">Bristol University</a>. He only took up refereeing after an <a href="/wiki/Eye_injury" title="Eye injury">eye injury</a> ended his playing career.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He officiated his first match in <a href="/wiki/Moseley" title="Moseley">Moseley</a> as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The <a href="/wiki/RFU" title="RFU" class="mw-redirect">RFU</a> were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.</p> <p>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford University</a> beat <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal to <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a> of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Titcomb later apologized for his call.</p> <p>Titcomb died of <a href="/wiki/Kidney_failure" title="Kidney failure" class="mw-redirect">kidney failure</a> on 2 May 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html">Referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>Planet Rugby</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/">Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75</a> <i>NBC Sports</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external <i>scrum.com</i></span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" He only took up refereeing after an [[eye injury]] ended his playing career.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html Referee Titcomb dies]  ''Planet Rugby''&lt;/ref&gt; He officiated his first match in [[Moseley]] as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The [[RFU]] were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.  </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when [[Oxford University]] beat [[South Africa]] 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</del>1968<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</del> when he wrongly awarded a drop goal [[Gareth Edwards]] of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-[[Ireland]] international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.&lt;ref&gt;[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/ Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75]  ''NBC Sports''&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849  Former referee Titcomb dies at 75]  ''24.com''&lt;/ref&gt; Titcomb later apologized for his call. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when [[Oxford University]] beat [[South Africa]] 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal [[Gareth Edwards]] of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-[[Ireland]] international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.&lt;ref&gt;[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/ Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75]  ''NBC Sports''&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849  Former referee Titcomb dies at 75] 2008.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php  Former top referee Titcomb dies]  ''scrum.com''&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Titcomb died of [[kidney failure]] on 2 May, 2008.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php  Former top referee Titcomb dies]  ''scrum.com''&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 15:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 15:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Titcomb, Mike}}</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Titcomb, Mike}}</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div><del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[Category:1933 births]]</del></div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div></div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:People from Bristol]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:People from Bristol]]</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 03:16, 18 December 2008</h2> <p><b>Michael Herbert Titcomb</b> (<a href="/wiki/23_April" title="23 April" class="mw-redirect">23 April</a>, <a href="/wiki/1933" title="1933">1933</a> - <a href="/wiki/2_May" title="2 May" class="mw-redirect">2 May</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008" title="2008">2008</a>) was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> referee. He became the youngest referee to officiate and international game when <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> in 1966.</p> <p>Born <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, <a href="/wiki/Bristol_University" title="Bristol University" class="mw-redirect">Bristol University</a>. He only took up refereeing after an <a href="/wiki/Eye_injury" title="Eye injury">eye injury</a> ended his playing career.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He officiated his first match in <a href="/wiki/Moseley" title="Moseley">Moseley</a> as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The <a href="/wiki/RFU" title="RFU" class="mw-redirect">RFU</a> were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.</p> <p>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford University</a> beat <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a> of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Titcomb later apologized for his call.</p> <p>Titcomb died of <a href="/wiki/Kidney_failure" title="Kidney failure" class="mw-redirect">kidney failure</a> on 2 May, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html">Referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>Planet Rugby</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/">Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75</a> <i>NBC Sports</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849">Former referee Titcomb dies at 75</a> <i>24.com</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php">Former top referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>scrum.com</i></span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when [[Oxford University]] beat [[South Africa]] 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">[[</del>1968<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">]]</del> when he wrongly awarded a drop goal [[Gareth Edwards]] of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-[[Ireland]] international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.&lt;ref&gt;[http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/ Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75]  ''NBC Sports''&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849  Former referee Titcomb dies at 75]  ''24.com''&lt;/ref&gt; Titcomb later apologized for his call. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when [[Oxford University]] beat [[South Africa]] 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal [[Gareth Edwards]] of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-[[Ireland]] international to 6-6. class="diff-addedline"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Titcomb, Mike}}</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td>   <td </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 11:30, 19 September 2008</h2> <p><b>Michael Herbert Titcomb</b> (<a href="/wiki/23_April" title="23 April" class="mw-redirect">23 April</a>, <a href="/wiki/1933" title="1933">1933</a> - <a href="/wiki/2_May" title="2 May" class="mw-redirect">2 May</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008" title="2008">2008</a>) was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> referee. He became the youngest referee to officiate and international game when <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> in 1966.</p> <p>Born <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, <a href="/wiki/Bristol_University" title="Bristol University" class="mw-redirect">Bristol University</a>. He only took up refereeing after an <a href="/wiki/Eye_injury" title="Eye injury">eye injury</a> ended his playing career.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He officiated his first match in <a href="/wiki/Moseley" title="Moseley">Moseley</a> as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The <a href="/wiki/RFU" title="RFU" class="mw-redirect">RFU</a> were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.</p> <p>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford University</a> beat <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in 1968 when he wrongly awarded a drop goal <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a> of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Titcomb later apologized for his call.</p> <p>Titcomb died of <a href="/wiki/Kidney_failure" title="Kidney failure" class="mw-redirect">kidney failure</a> on 2 May, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html">Referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>Planet Rugby</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/">Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75</a> <i>NBC Sports</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849">Former referee Titcomb dies at 75</a> <i>24.com</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php">Former top referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>scrum.com</i></span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3882185.ece">The Times - Obituary</a></li> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" Carty">contribs</a>)</span> </div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle3"> <span class="comment">(<a href="#External_links">→</a>‎<span dir="auto"><span class="autocomment">External links: </span> category</span>)</span></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle5"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle4"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Titcomb&amp;diff=next&amp;oldid=211723159" title="Mike Titcomb" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr><td colspan='4' style='text-align: center;' class='diff-multi'>(One intermediate revision by one other user not shown)</td></tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>'''Michael Herbert Titcomb''' ([[23 April]], [[1933]] - [[2 May]], [[2008]]) was a [[rugby union]] referee. The [[RFU]] were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.  </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Born [[Bristol]], [[England]] Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, [[Bristol University]]. </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>*[http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2008/may/06/rugbyunion The Guardian - Obituary]   </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>{{DEFAULTSORT:Titcomb, Mike}}</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 19:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 20:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:English rugby union referees]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:English rugby union referees]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Alumni of the University of Bristol]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:Alumni of the University of Bristol]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Deaths from renal failure]]</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 20:29, 11 May 2008</h2> <p><b>Michael Herbert Titcomb</b> (<a href="/wiki/23_April" title="23 April" class="mw-redirect">23 April</a>, <a href="/wiki/1933" title="1933">1933</a> - <a href="/wiki/2_May" title="2 May" class="mw-redirect">2 May</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008" title="2008">2008</a>) was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> referee. He became the youngest referee to officiate and international game when <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> in <a href="/wiki/1966" title="1966">1966</a>.</p> <p>Born <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, <a href="/wiki/Bristol_University" title="Bristol University" class="mw-redirect">Bristol University</a>. He only took up refereeing after an <a href="/wiki/Eye_injury" title="Eye injury">eye injury</a> ended his playing career.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He officiated his first match in <a href="/wiki/Moseley" title="Moseley">Moseley</a> as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The <a href="/wiki/RFU" title="RFU" class="mw-redirect">RFU</a> were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.</p> <p>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford University</a> beat <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in <a href="/wiki/1968" title="1968">1968</a> when he wrongly awarded a drop goal <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a> of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Titcomb later apologized for his call.</p> <p>Titcomb died of <a href="/wiki/Kidney_failure" title="Kidney failure" class="mw-redirect">kidney failure</a> on 2 May, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html">Referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>Planet Rugby</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/">Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75</a> <i>NBC Sports</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.24.com/sport/?p=rugby_article&amp;i=837849">Former referee Titcomb dies at 75</a> <i>24.com</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php">Former top referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>scrum.com</i></span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" The [[RFU]] were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.  </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>Born [[Bristol]], [[England]] Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, [[Bristol University]]. He only took up refereeing after an [[eye injury]] ended his playing career.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html Referee Titcomb dies]  ''Planet Rugby''&lt;/ref&gt; He officiated his first match in [[Moseley]] as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The [[RFU]] were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.  </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 16:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 16:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:People from Bristol]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:English rugby union referees]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:English rugby union referees]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Alumni of the University of Bristol]]</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 23:09, 10 May 2008</h2> <p><b>Michael Herbert Titcomb</b> (<a href="/wiki/23_April" title="23 April" class="mw-redirect">23 April</a>, <a href="/wiki/1933" title="1933">1933</a> - <a href="/wiki/2_May" title="2 May" class="mw-redirect">2 May</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008" title="2008">2008</a>) was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> referee. He became the youngest referee to officiate and international game when <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> in <a href="/wiki/1966" title="1966">1966</a>.</p> <p>Born <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, <a href="/wiki/Bristol_University" title="Bristol University" class="mw-redirect">Bristol University</a>. He only took up refereeing after an <a href="/wiki/Eye_injury" title="Eye injury">eye injury</a> ended his playing career.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He officiated his first match in <a href="/wiki/Moseley" title="Moseley">Moseley</a> as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The <a href="/wiki/RFU" title="RFU" class="mw-redirect">RFU</a> were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.</p> <p>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford University</a> beat <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in <a href="/wiki/1968" title="1968">1968</a> when he wrongly awarded a drop goal <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a> of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Titcomb later apologized for his call.</p> <p>Titcomb died of <a href="/wiki/Kidney_failure" title="Kidney failure" class="mw-redirect">kidney failure</a> on 2 May, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" age 75</a> <i>NBC Sports</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external <i>scrum.com</i></span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" Carty">contribs</a>)</span> </div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle3"> <span class="comment">(<a href="#External_links">→</a>‎<span dir="auto"><span class="autocomment">External links: </span> category</span>)</span></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle5"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle4"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Mike_Titcomb&amp;diff=next&amp;oldid=210990301" title="Mike Titcomb" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 16:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 16:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:1933 births]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:2008 deaths]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:People from Bristol]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:English rugby union referees]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:English rugby union referees]]</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 08:37, 8 May 2008</h2> <p><b>Michael Herbert Titcomb</b> (<a href="/wiki/23_April" title="23 April" class="mw-redirect">23 April</a>, <a href="/wiki/1933" title="1933">1933</a> - <a href="/wiki/2_May" title="2 May" class="mw-redirect">2 May</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008" title="2008">2008</a>) was a <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> referee. He became the youngest referee to officiate and international game when <a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a> faced <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a>.</p> <p>Born <a href="/wiki/Bristol" title="Bristol">Bristol</a>, <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> Titcomb played rugby for both his school and his university, <a href="/wiki/Bristol_University" title="Bristol University" class="mw-redirect">Bristol University</a>. He only took up refereeing after an <a href="/wiki/Eye_injury" title="Eye injury">eye injury</a> ended his playing career.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> He officiated his first match in <a href="/wiki/Moseley" title="Moseley">Moseley</a> as the substitute referee when the one originally scheduled failed to show. The <a href="/wiki/RFU" title="RFU" class="mw-redirect">RFU</a> were impressed by his performance and Titcomb quickly made it to the international ranks.</p> <p>He officiated five England Trails, three Barbarian fixtures and 26 county matches, including three finals. Several of the matches he refereed are well remembered including when <a href="/wiki/Oxford_University" title="Oxford University" class="mw-redirect">Oxford University</a> beat <a href="/wiki/South_Africa" title="South Africa">South Africa</a> 6-3. The most famous moment of his career came in <a href="/wiki/1968" title="1968">1968</a> when he wrongly awarded a drop goal <a href="/wiki/Gareth_Edwards" title="Gareth Edwards">Gareth Edwards</a> of Wales. With the call it brought the score of the Wales-<a href="/wiki/Ireland" title="Ireland">Ireland</a> international to 6-6. The Irish fans acted with anger to Titcomb's call pelting him with bottles and other missiles as he left the pitch at the end of the game.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> Titcomb later apologized for his call.</p> <p>Titcomb died of <a href="/wiki/Kidney_failure" title="Kidney failure" class="mw-redirect">kidney failure</a> on 2 May, 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.planet-rugby.com/Story/0,18259,3551_3529999,00.html">Referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>Planet Rugby</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/24500286/">Former rugby union referee Mike Titcomb dies at age 75</a> <i>NBC Sports</i></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scrum.com/39_53657.php">Former top referee Titcomb dies</a> <i>scrum.com</i></span></li> </ol> </div> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2> <ul> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3882185.ece">The Times - Obituary</a></li> <li><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2008/may/06/rugbyunion">The Guardian - Obituary</a></li> </ul>   <!--  NewPP limit report Parsed by mw1105 CPU time usage: 0.049 seconds Real time usage: 0.057 It allows adding a reason in the summary.">undo</a>)</span></strong></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle2"><a href="/w/index.php?title=User:Billyfutile&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new mw-userlink" title="User:Billyfutile (page does not exist)">Billyfutile</a> <span class="mw-usertoollinks">(<a href="/wiki/User_talk:Billyfutile" title="User talk:Billyfutile">talk</a> | <a href="/wiki/Special:Contributions/Billyfutile" title="Special:Contributions/Billyfutile">contribs</a>)</span> </div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle3"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle5"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle4"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Murder_of_Jennifer_Daugherty&amp;diff=next&amp;oldid=439367364" title="Murder of Jennifer Daugherty" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr><td colspan='4' style='text-align: center;' class='diff-multi'>(One intermediate revision by one other user not shown)</td></tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div><del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">The </del>'''<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">murder of </del>Jennifer Lee Daugherty''' (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">committed</del> in [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania|Greensburg]], [[Pennsylvania]] in February 2010.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime], The New York Times, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; Daugherty, who was [[Mental retardation|mentally disabled]], was [[Torture murder|tortured and murdered]] before being wrapped in [[Christmas decoration]]s, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested|work=True Crime Report|location=New York|url=http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php|accessdate=09-30-2010|first=Pete|last=Kotz|date=February 19, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>'''Jennifer Lee Daugherty''' (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">murdered</ins> in [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania|Greensburg]], [[Pennsylvania]] in February 2010.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime], The New York Times, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; Daugherty, who was [[Mental retardation|mentally disabled]], was [[Torture murder|tortured and murdered]] before being wrapped in [[Christmas decoration]]s, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested|work=True Crime Report|location=New York|url=http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php|accessdate=09-30-2010|first=Pete|last=Kotz|date=February 19, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>During [[torture]] and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume [[feces]] and [[urine]]&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death|date=March 5, 2010|accessdate=09-30-2010|work=Pittsburgh Channel|location=Pittsburgh|url=http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10063/1040265-100.stm 6 held for trial in Greensburg torture, slaying], Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, March 4, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; and [[detergent]]; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake [[suicide note]]; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/16/crimesider/entry6212578.shtml Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled Woman, Trusted Everyone, Including Her Killers], CBS News, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>During [[torture]] and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume [[feces]] and [[urine]]&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death|date=March 5, 2010|accessdate=09-30-2010|work=Pittsburgh Channel|location=Pittsburgh|url=http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10063/1040265-100.stm 6 held for trial in Greensburg torture, slaying], Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, March 4, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; and [[detergent]]; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake [[suicide note]]; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/16/crimesider/entry6212578.shtml Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled Woman, Trusted Everyone, Including Her Killers], CBS News, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 19:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 19:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:American murder victims]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td> Pennsylvania]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>[[Category:People murdered in Pennsylvania]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>[[Category:Deaths by person]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{crime-stub}}</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>{{crime-stub}}</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 02:46, 14 July 2011</h2> <p><b>Jennifer Lee Daugherty</b> (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was murdered in <a href="/wiki/Greensburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Greensburg, Pennsylvania">Greensburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> in February 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Daugherty, who was <a href="/wiki/Mental_retardation" title="Mental retardation" class="mw-redirect">mentally disabled</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Torture_murder" title="Torture murder" class="mw-redirect">tortured and murdered</a> before being wrapped in <a href="/wiki/Christmas_decoration" title="Christmas decoration">Christmas decorations</a>, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>During <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a> and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume <a href="/wiki/Feces" title="Feces">feces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urine" title="Urine">urine</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Detergent" title="Detergent">detergent</a>; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake <a href="/wiki/Suicide_note" title="Suicide note">suicide note</a>; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> According to her relatives, Daugherty had the mental abilities of a 12- to 14-year-old, she trusted everyone, and she had thought that the suspects were her "friends."<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Allegheny County Coroner <a href="/wiki/Cyril_H._Wecht" title="Cyril H. Wecht" class="mw-redirect">Cyril H. Wecht</a>, who has conducted and reviewed thousands of autopsies of homicide victims, stated, "... This is one of the most horrific cases I have seen... You have one young, defenseless woman, six people who are keeping her captive and doing all of these things, knowing she is [mentally challenged]. Put it all together, it is bizarre, it is extreme barbarism."<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> <ul> <li><a href="/wiki/Sadistic_personality_disorder" title="Sadistic personality disorder">Sadistic personality disorder</a></li> <li><a href="/wiki/Torture_murder" title="Torture murder" class="mw-redirect">Torture murder</a></li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html">Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime</a>, The New York Times, February 16, 2010</span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="citation news">Kotz, Pete (February 19, 2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php">"Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested"</a>. <i>True Crime Report</i> (New York)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved 09-30-2010</span>.</span><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMurder+of+Jennifer+Daugherty&amp;rft.atitle=Jennifer+Daugherty%2C+Mentally+Disabled%2C+was+Tortured+%26+Murdered+by+Her+%27Friends%27%3B+6+Arrested&amp;rft.aufirst=Pete&amp;rft.au=Kotz%2C+Pete&amp;rft.aulast=Kotz&amp;rft.date=February+19%2C+2010&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.truecrimereport.com%2F2010%2F02%2Fjennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php&amp;rft.jtitle=True+Crime+Report&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span> <span style="font-size:100%" class="error citation-comment">Check date values in: <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">|accessdate=</code> (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#bad_date" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html">"Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death"</a>. <i>Pittsburgh Channel</i> (Pittsburgh). 13, 2010</span></li> <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="#p-search">search</a> 				</div> 				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><table class='diff diff-contentalign-left'> 				<col class='diff-marker' /> 				<col id="mw-diff-otitle2"><a href="/wiki/User:Keri" title="User:Keri" class="mw-userlink">Keri</a> <span class="mw-usertoollinks">(<a href="/wiki/User_talk:Keri" title="User talk:Keri">talk</a> | <a href="/w/index.php?title=Murder_of_Jennifer_Daugherty&amp;diff=prev&amp;oldid=387893686" title="Murder of Jennifer Daugherty" id="differences-prevlink">← Previous edit</a></div></td> 				<td colspan='2' class='diff-ntitle'><div id="mw-diff-ntitle1"><strong><a href="/w/index.php?title=Murder_of_Jennifer_Daugherty&amp;oldid=403270792" title="Murder of Jennifer Daugherty">Revision as of Daugherty">edit</a>)</span> <span class="mw-diff-undo">(<a href="/w/index.php?title=Murder_of_Jennifer_Daugherty&amp;action=edit&amp;undoafter=387893686&amp;undo=403270792" title="&quot;Undo&quot; It allows adding a reason in the summary.">undo</a>)</span></strong></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle2"><a href="/wiki/Special:Contributions/87.79.115.146" title="Special:Contributions/87.79.115.146" class="mw-userlink mw-anonuserlink">87.79.115.146</a> <span class="mw-usertoollinks">(<a href="/w/index.php?title=User_talk:87.79.115.146&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="User talk:87.79.115.146 (page does not exist)">talk</a>)</span> </div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle3"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle5"></div><div id="mw-diff-ntitle4"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Murder_of_Jennifer_Daugherty&amp;diff=next&amp;oldid=403270792" title="Murder of Jennifer Daugherty" id="differences-nextlink">Next edit →</a></div></td> 				</tr><tr><td colspan='4' style='text-align: center;' class='diff-multi'>(One intermediate revision by one other user not shown)</td></tr><tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 1:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div><del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">The </del>'''<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">murder of </del>Jennifer Lee Daugherty''' (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">committed</del> in [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania|Greensburg]], [[Pennsylvania]] in February 2010.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime], The New York Times, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; Daugherty, who was [[Mental retardation|mentally disabled]], was [[Torture murder|tortured and murdered]] before being wrapped in [[Christmas decoration]]s, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested|work=True Crime Report|location=New York|url=http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php|accessdate=09-30-2010|first=Pete|last=Kotz|date=February 19, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; </div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>'''Jennifer Lee Daugherty''' (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">murdered</ins> in [[Greensburg, Pennsylvania|Greensburg]], [[Pennsylvania]] in February 2010.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime], The New York Times, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; Daugherty, who was [[Mental retardation|mentally disabled]], was [[Torture murder|tortured and murdered]] before being wrapped in [[Christmas decoration]]s, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested|work=True Crime Report|location=New York|url=http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php|accessdate=09-30-2010|first=Pete|last=Kotz|date=February 19, 2010}}&lt;/ref&gt; </div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>During [[torture]] and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume [[feces]] and [[urine]]&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death|date=March 5, 2010|accessdate=09-30-2010|work=Pittsburgh Channel|location=Pittsburgh|url=http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10063/1040265-100.stm 6 held for trial in Greensburg torture, slaying], Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, March 4, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; and [[detergent]]; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake [[suicide note]]; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/16/crimesider/entry6212578.shtml Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled Woman, Trusted Everyone, Including Her Killers], CBS News, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>During [[torture]] and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume [[feces]] and [[urine]]&lt;ref&gt;{{Cite news|title=Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death|date=March 5, 2010|accessdate=09-30-2010|work=Pittsburgh Channel|location=Pittsburgh|url=http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html}}&lt;/ref&gt;&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10063/1040265-100.stm 6 held for trial in Greensburg torture, slaying], Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, March 4, 2010&lt;/ref&gt; and [[detergent]]; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake [[suicide note]]; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/16/crimesider/entry6212578.shtml Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled Woman, Trusted Everyone, Including Her Killers], CBS News, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 8:</td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-lineno">Line 8:</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==See also==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==See also==</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>* [[Sadistic personality disorder]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>* [[Sadistic personality disorder]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>* [[<del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Murder</del> <del class="diffchange diffchange-inline">of Suzanne Capper</del>]]</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">+</td>   <td class="diff-addedline"><div>* [[<ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">Torture</ins> <ins class="diffchange diffchange-inline">murder</ins>]]</div></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">−</td>   <td class="diff-deletedline"><div>* [[Murder of Kelly Anne Bates]]</div></td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"></td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==References==</div></td>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>==References==</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 01:14, 20 December 2010</h2> <p><b>Jennifer Lee Daugherty</b> (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was murdered in <a href="/wiki/Greensburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Greensburg, Pennsylvania">Greensburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> in February 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Daugherty, who was <a href="/wiki/Mental_retardation" title="Mental retardation" class="mw-redirect">mentally disabled</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Torture_murder" title="Torture murder" class="mw-redirect">tortured and murdered</a> before being wrapped in <a href="/wiki/Christmas_decoration" title="Christmas decoration">Christmas decorations</a>, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>During <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a> and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume <a href="/wiki/Feces" title="Feces">feces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urine" title="Urine">urine</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Detergent" title="Detergent">detergent</a>; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake <a href="/wiki/Suicide_note" title="Suicide note">suicide note</a>; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> According to her relatives, Daugherty had the mental abilities of a 12- to 14-year-old, she trusted everyone, and she had thought that the suspects were her "friends."<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Allegheny County Coroner <a href="/wiki/Cyril_H._Wecht" title="Cyril H. Wecht" class="mw-redirect">Cyril H. Wecht</a>, who has conducted and reviewed thousands of autopsies of homicide victims, stated, "... This is one of the most horrific cases I have seen... You have one young, defenseless woman, six people who are keeping her captive and doing all of these things, knowing she is [mentally challenged]. Put it all together, it is bizarre, it is extreme barbarism."<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> <ul> <li><a href="/wiki/Sadistic_personality_disorder" title="Sadistic personality disorder">Sadistic personality disorder</a></li> <li><a href="/wiki/Torture_murder" title="Torture murder" class="mw-redirect">Torture murder</a></li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html">Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime</a>, The New York Times, February 16, 2010</span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="citation news">Kotz, Pete (February 19, 2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php">"Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested"</a>. <i>True Crime Report</i> (New York)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved 09-30-2010</span>.</span><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMurder+of+Jennifer+Daugherty&amp;rft.atitle=Jennifer+Daugherty%2C+Mentally+Disabled%2C+was+Tortured+%26+Murdered+by+Her+%27Friends%27%3B+6+Arrested&amp;rft.aufirst=Pete&amp;rft.au=Kotz%2C+Pete&amp;rft.aulast=Kotz&amp;rft.date=February+19%2C+2010&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.truecrimereport.com%2F2010%2F02%2Fjennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php&amp;rft.jtitle=True+Crime+Report&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span> <span style="font-size:100%" class="error citation-comment">Check date values in: <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">|accessdate=</code> (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#bad_date" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html">"Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death"</a>. <i>Pittsburgh Channel</i> (Pittsburgh). March 5, 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved 09-30-2010</span>.</span><span 13, 2010</span></li> <li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.&lt;ref&gt;[http://www.cbsnews.com/blogs/2010/02/16/crimesider/entry6212578.shtml Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled Woman, Trusted Everyone, Including Her Killers], CBS News, February 16, 2010&lt;/ref&gt;</div></td>   <td colspan="2" class="diff-empty">&#160;</td> </tr> <tr>   <td class="diff-marker">&#160;</td>   <td class="diff-context"><div>According to her relatives, Daugherty had the mental abilities of a 12- to 14-year-old, she trusted everyone, and she had thought that class="diff-context"><div>==References==</div></td> </tr> </table><hr class='diff-hr' id='mw-oldid' /> 		<h2 class='diff-currentversion-title'>Revision as of 23:25, 9 December 2010</h2> <p>The <b>murder of Jennifer Lee Daugherty</b> (November 8, 1979 – February 11, 2010) was committed in <a href="/wiki/Greensburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Greensburg, Pennsylvania">Greensburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> in February 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup> Daugherty, who was <a href="/wiki/Mental_retardation" title="Mental retardation" class="mw-redirect">mentally disabled</a>, was <a href="/wiki/Torture_murder" title="Torture murder" class="mw-redirect">tortured and murdered</a> before being wrapped in <a href="/wiki/Christmas_decoration" title="Christmas decoration">Christmas decorations</a>, put inside a garbage can and dumped in the parking lot of Greensburg Salem Middle School.<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>During <a href="/wiki/Torture" title="Torture">torture</a> and abuse sessions, which lasted for 36 hours, Daugherty's attackers tied her up, forced her to consume <a href="/wiki/Feces" title="Feces">feces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Urine" title="Urine">urine</a><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Detergent" title="Detergent">detergent</a>; beat her with a towel rack, a vacuum cleaner hose, and a crutch; shaved her head; painted her face with nail polish; forced her to write a fake <a href="/wiki/Suicide_note" title="Suicide note">suicide note</a>; and then stabbed her to death. Six suspects were charged with criminal homicide, kidnapping and other counts related to her death.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> According to her relatives, Daugherty had the mental abilities of a 12- to 14-year-old, she trusted everyone, and she had thought that the suspects were her "friends."<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <p>Allegheny County Coroner <a href="/wiki/Cyril_H._Wecht" title="Cyril H. Wecht" class="mw-redirect">Cyril H. Wecht</a>, who has conducted and reviewed thousands of autopsies of homicide victims, stated, "... This is one of the most horrific cases I have seen... You have one young, defenseless woman, six people who are keeping her captive and doing all of these things, knowing she is [mentally challenged]. Put it all together, it is bizarre, it is extreme barbarism."<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup></p> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> <ul> <li><a href="/wiki/Sadistic_personality_disorder" title="Sadistic personality disorder">Sadistic personality disorder</a></li> <li><a href="/wiki/Torture_murder" title="Torture murder" class="mw-redirect">Torture murder</a></li> </ul> <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2> <div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;"> <ol class="references"> <li id="cite_note-1"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-1">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2010/02/16/us/AP-US-Disabled-Woman-Torture.html">Feds: Pa. Torture Death Might Be Hate Crime</a>, The New York Times, February 16, 2010</span></li> <li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="citation news">Kotz, Pete (February 19, 2010). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.truecrimereport.com/2010/02/jennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php">"Jennifer Daugherty, Mentally Disabled, was Tortured &amp; Murdered by Her 'Friends'; 6 Arrested"</a>. <i>True Crime Report</i> (New York)<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved 09-30-2010</span>.</span><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AMurder+of+Jennifer+Daugherty&amp;rft.atitle=Jennifer+Daugherty%2C+Mentally+Disabled%2C+was+Tortured+%26+Murdered+by+Her+%27Friends%27%3B+6+Arrested&amp;rft.aufirst=Pete&amp;rft.au=Kotz%2C+Pete&amp;rft.aulast=Kotz&amp;rft.date=February+19%2C+2010&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.truecrimereport.com%2F2010%2F02%2Fjennifer_daugherty_mentally_di.php&amp;rft.jtitle=True+Crime+Report&amp;rft.place=New+York&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal" class="Z3988"><span style="display:none;">&#160;</span></span> <span style="font-size:100%" class="error citation-comment">Check date values in: <code style="color:inherit; border:inherit; padding:inherit;">|accessdate=</code> (<a href="/wiki/Help:CS1_errors#bad_date" title="Help:CS1 errors">help</a>)</span></span></li> <li id="cite_note-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-3">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><span class="citation news"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.thepittsburghchannel.com/news/22737470/detail.html">"Graphic Tapes Describe Jennifer Daugherty's Torture Death"</a>. <i>Pittsburgh Channel</i> (Pittsburgh). March 5, 2010<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved 09-30-2010</span>.</span><span
